title-group.subtitle: Clockwise Movements Increase Preference for Novelty

fn.p: Sascha Topolinski is a postdoctoral in the Department of Fritz Strack of the University of Wuerzburg. He has gained his PhD from the University of Wuerzburg in 2009. His work primarily focuses on intuition and embodiment.
Peggy Sparenberg is a PhD student from the Max-Planck Institute Leipzig in the working of Wolfgang Prinz. Her work is dedicated to action effects and mental simulation.

abstract.p: The omnipresent abstract symbol for time progression and regression is clockwise versus counterclockwise rotation. It was tested whether merely executing and seeing clockwise (vs. counterclockwise) movements would induce psychological states of temporal progression (vs. regression) and according to motivational orientations toward the future and novelty (vs. the past and familiarity). Supporting this hypothesis, participants who turned cranks counterclockwise preferred familiar over novel stimuli, but participants who turned cranks clockwise preferred novel over old stimuli, reversing the classic mere exposure effect (Experiment 1). Also, participants rotating a cylinder clockwise reported higher scores in the personality measure openness to experience than participants rotating counterclockwise (Experiment 2). Merely passively watching a rotating square had similar but weaker effects on exposure and openness (Experiment 3). Finally, participants chose more unconventional candies from a clockwise than from a counterclockwise Lazy Susan, that is, a turntable (Experiment 4).

body.p: The mental representation of time heavily draws on spatial information (Boroditsky, 2000, 2001; Casasanto & Boroditsky, 2008). For instance, the succession from past to future events can be mentally organized from left to right or from back to front relative to one’s own body (Casasanto & Boroditsky, 2008). Beyond these visual representations, time–space mappings can even involve bodily (i.e., sensorimotor) components: when we think of the future, we slightly lean forward (Miles, Nind, & Macrae, 2010) and being apparently moved forward makes us think of the future in turn (Miles, Karpinska, Lumsden, & Macrae, 2010). Thus, the abstract concept of time is multimodally represented (cf., Lakoff & Johnson, 1999).

Beyond such static time–space mappings, dynamic time symbols may also exist. One universal example for this is the rotational direction of clock hands. Clockwise movement indicates time passing by, thus progression to the future; whereas counterclockwise movement indicates reversal of time, and thus regression to the past. This assignment of meaning is arbitrary and only due to the historic fact that the predecessors of modern clocks, namely sundials, were invented in the northern hemisphere where in the course of the day the sun’s path across the sky is clockwise (Rohr, 1996).

Nevertheless, the association of clockwise/progression and counterclockwise/regression is a universal perceptual symbol (cf., Barsalou, 1999), for instance, on analog clocks or the “recycling symbol.” Beyond these merely visual cases, rotational direction has become a ubiquitous motion metaphor involving our own body movements, such as when we operate iPods, the car ignition, the volume control, or a can opener (Zwaan & Taylor, 2006). In all these cases, a clockwise rotation signifies a progression toward the current goal or the tool’s purpose. This is even true for many cases that seem contradictory or disputable at first sight. For instance, to open a bottle and get the drink, we have to turn the bottle cap in a counterclockwise direction. However, for caps being closure mechanisms (similar to screws) again the clockwise turning direction indicates a progression toward its functional purpose, namely, closing the bottle or tightening a connection.

Thus, the abstract spatial movement feature of rotational direction is linked with progression/regression by massive sensorimotor experience during everyday life, including visual (e.g., clocks) and motor (e.g., operating a volume control) representations (Barsalou, 1999; Boroditsky, 2001). Thus, the question is whether rotational direction—perceptually and or motorically—might activate respective future- and past-related orientations (Boroditsky, 2000, 2001; Casasanto & Boroditsky, 2008) and thus trigger psychological states of temporal progression and regression. Such states may shape psychological processes beyond mere thought content (Gilbert & Wilson, 2007; Miles, Karpinska, et al., 2010) and may involve whole motivational orientations and attitudes toward the past and the future, as outlined in the following.

An essential psychological corollary of progression in time is the experience of novelty (James, 1890; Kant, 1929), while regression to the past is a return to the old and familiar (Freud, 1965). Because particularly heading toward the future essentially requires dealing with novel events and experiences, a progressive compared to a regressive mind-set should necessarily entail a novelty orientation, that is, a preference for novel stimuli (Bardo, Donohew, & Harrington, 1996; cf., novelty seeking, Roberti, 2004; Zuckerman, 1984). Consequently, if clockwise/counterclockwise rotation induces progression (vs. regression), then clockwise compared to counterclockwise rotation should increase novelty preference, functioning like a cognitive tuning (cf., Mavis, 1973; Schwarz, 2002; see also Smallwood & Schooler, 2006).

The present studies tested this hypothesis. As inductions of rotational direction, we used both motor (Experiments 1 and 2) and visual (Experiment 3) instantiations because the mapping between rotational and temporal direction seems multimodal (see above). To avoid conscious clock-related associations (e.g., by a dot moving circularly), we used inductions featuring the smallest possible similarity with clocks, for instance turning cranks, or a rotating square. As dependent variables, we assessed different motivational and behavioral measures of novelty orientation, namely, preference for familiar versus novel stimuli (Zajonc, 1968), self-reported openness to novelty (McCrae, 1996), as well as overt exploration behavior (Berlyne, 1950; Hughes, 1997), to demonstrate the breadth of the present effect.

sec.title: Experiment 1: Preference for Familiarity and Novelty
sec.p: In general, people prefer familiar over novel stimuli, which is the classic mere exposure effect (Zajonc, 1968). We predicted that a clockwise body movement (turning a crank) by inducing mental progression and an accordingly exploration mind-set (cf., Hansen & Topolinski, 2011) would attenuate or even reverse this preference for familiarity (cf., De Vries, Holland, Chenier, Starr, & Winkielman, 2010).

sec.title: Pilot Studies
sec.p: In two studies, the general prevalence and valence of clockwise/counterclockwise movements was assessed in independent samples.

sec.title: Prevalence of Turning Directions
sec.p: Although Experiment 2 controlled for the affective valence and execution effort of clockwise/counterclockwise movements, it is possible that one of these turning directions is more prevalent or easy than the other, for instance due to ecological or biomechanical factors. This difference between the common and unusual turning direction would allow alternative mechanisms to work, such as mood (cf., De Vries et al., 2010), heuristic versus systematic processing style (Schwarz, 2002), or motor fluency (Topolinski, 2010; Topolinski & Strack, 2009, 2010). Thus, a possible preponderance of either clockwise or counterclockwise movements was tested using a daily motor routine. A total of 66 individuals received an empty cup and a spoon and were asked to spontaneously pantomime a person who stirs a coffee, while the used hand and the stirring direction were registered unobtrusively. While there were more participants using their right (54 of 66, 82%) than their left hand (12 of 66, 18%), t(65) = 6.65, p < .001, there was no difference in the numbers of clockwise (35 of 66, 53%) and counterclockwise stirrers (31 of 66, 47%), p = .60.

sec.title: Pleasantness of Turning Cranks
sec.p: A total of 47 participants were asked to turn the cranks used in the main experiment (see below) in a clockwise (n = 24) or counterclockwise (n = 23) direction for 2 min and to rate how pleasant (0 = very unpleasant and 10 = very pleasant) the movement was. No reliable difference occurred (M clockwise = 7.13, SD = 1.26; M counterclockwise = 6.83, SD = 1.86; p = .60).

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: A total of 50 students (35 female and 15 male; 42 right-handers and 8 left-handers) from various disciplines of the University of Leipzig participated for a reward of €2 (approximately US$3 then).

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: As to-be-moved gadgets, we used cranks, that is, a platform on a desk with two movable round plates with a knob placed on each. As stimuli, we used a pool of 20 Chinese ideographs (cf., Zajonc, 1968; Topolinski & Strack, 2009).

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: The study was introduced as an investigation of multitasking involving arm movements and vision judgments such as during car driving. Participants were seated at the desk with the two cranks and were asked to turn the cranks continuously during the whole task using one hand per crank (Figure 1A). Between participants, the turning direction (clockwise vs. counterclockwise) was varied (n = 25 in each condition). Importantly, to avoid semantic labeling effects of the current movement trajectory (cf., Eder & Rothermund, 2008), this direction was not instructed by semantic labels (such as “to the right,” or “clockwise”) but rather by a schematic depiction (Figure 1B).

caption.p: The motor tasks and instructions used in Experiments 1, 3, and 4.

sec.p: While turning the cranks, participants watched Chinese ideographs on a PC screen in front of them. In a study phase, 10 randomly chosen Chinese ideographs were presented for 1,000 ms each and 2,000 ms interitem interval. After a break of 1 min, these already presented ideographs were shown again (with the same presentation timings) randomly mixed with 10 novel ideographs in random order. Participants were asked to indicate their liking of each appearing stimulus by briefly interrupting their turning exercise and pressing a button on a scale from 1 (I do not like it at all) to 7 (I like it a lot; test phase).

sec.title: Debriefing
sec.p: After the task, a PC-directed debriefing probed for participants’ suspicions concerning the purpose of the experiment beyond the multitasking perspective in the cover story. No participant reported a suspicion concerning the turning directions or preference for old and novel stimuli. Also, in the following experiments, no valid suspicions were reported. Thus, we will leave out the report of the debriefing.

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p: A 2 (Exposure: old items, new items; within) × 2 (Turning Direction: clockwise, counterclockwise; between) analysis of variance (ANOVA) solely yielded an interaction between Exposure and Turning Direction, F(1, 48) = 15.93, p < .0001, ηp 2 = .25, and no other effects (ps < .30). Participants who had turned the cranks counterclockwise liked old stimuli (M counterclockwise-old = 4.46, SD = 0.59) more than novel stimuli (M counterclockwise-new = 4.10, SD = 0.57), t(24) = 3.64, p < .001, d = 0.62, replicating the classic mere exposure effect. In contrast, however, participants who turned the cranks clockwise liked old stimuli (M counterclockwise-old = 3.95, SD = 0.86) less than novel stimuli (M counterclockwise-new = 4.27, SD = 0.85), reversing the mere exposure effect, t(24) = 2.30, p < .031, d = 0.36. This pattern was not moderated by participants’ handedness (cf., Casasanto, 2009).

Although participants were not aware of the relation between turning direction and the preference for old and novel stimuli, a meaningless body movement could reverse the classic mere exposure effect (Zajonc, 1968). Note that the two experimental conditions (clockwise vs. counterclockwise) were completely balanced on various motor and valence aspects, such as the amount of arm flexion versus extension (Cacioppo, Priester, & Berntson, 1993), up–down and right–left motion trajectories (Casasanto, 2009; Eder & Rothermund, 2008), and right and left hemisphere involvement (Cretenet & Dru, 2004), rendering the accordingly alternative motivational explanations unlikely (which also applies to the following experiments).

sec.title: Experiment 2: Openness to Experience
sec.p: As another indicator of novelty preference, we assessed conscious attitudes toward novelty, namely self-reported experiential openness (Costa & McCrae, 1992; also related to sensation seeking, Roberti, 2004) during rotational movements. Furthermore, we generalized the present effects to a motor task that did not involve a circular movement of the body itself but a rotation of the manipulated object.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: A total of 60 (47 female and 13 male; 56 right-handers and 4 left-handers) German undergraduate students from various disciplines participated for a reward of €1 (approximately US$1.50 then).

sec.title: Material
sec.p: The openness to experience subscale of the Neuroticism–Extroversion–Openness Personality Inventory (NEO PI-R; Costa & McCrae, 1992; German version Borkenau & Ostendorf, 1993) was used, assessing a general preference for novel experiences and actions (Costa & McCrae, 1992; McCrae, 1996). Example items are “I often try new and foreign food” and “Poetry does not deeply impress me” (reversed). As to-be-rotated objects, two ordinary kitchen paper towels were sealed with plastic (so that the paper would not unfold when spun) and slipped loosely over upright wooden rods (see Figure 1C). Both rods were fixed on a wooden board with a distance of 50 cm between them so that the two paper towels could easily be manipulated using both arms. The rotating direction was instructed nonverbally by a schematic description (Figure 1D).

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Participants were instructed to continuously rotate the two paper towels using the palms of their hands (Figure 1A) while reading each personality item and to stop rotating only to use the computer mouse to render their ratings on a 5-point scale from −2 (strongly disagree) to +2 (strongly agree). Then, participants were asked to report their current mood (0 = very bad and 10 = very good) and arousal (0 = very relaxed and 10 = very aroused/excited) while still rotating. Crucially, the turning direction of the paper towels was either clockwise or counterclockwise (n = 30 in each condition). Note that these arm movements were again balanced for approach–avoidance, up–down, and right–left components (Cacioppo et al., 1993; Casasanto, 2009; Cretenet & Dru, 2004; Eder & Rothermund, 2008).

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p: After recoding the reversed items, the 12 openness to experience items (Cronbach’s α = .58) were averaged for each participant. Resulting scores ranged from −0.33 to 1.5 (M = 0.72, SD = 0.52). Participants who had turned the paper towels clockwise reported higher openness to experience (M clockwise = 0.86, SD = 0.44) than participants who had turned them counterclockwise (M counterclockwise = 0.58, SD = 0.55), t(58) = 2.21, p < .031, d = 0.58; when controlling for participants’ mood valence and arousal, F(1, 56) = 6.54, p < .013, ηp 2 = .11. Mood and arousal, however, did not differ between the clockwise (M mood-clockwise = 6.13, SD = 1.68; M arousal-clockwise = 4.47, SD = 1.85) and the counterclockwise turning groups (M mood-counterclockwise = 6.43, SD = 2.01; M arousal-counterclockwise = 4.63, SD = 1.83), ps > .50. Again, handedness did not moderate this pattern.

Thus, even self-reported experiential openness, which is conceptualized as a rather stable personality trait (Costa & McCrae, 1992), was affected by rotational direction. The body movements in the present task were not circular themselves—but rather linear—and only effected an object rotation (cf., action-effects, Topolinski, 2011).

sec.title: Experiment 3: Visual Rotation and Novelty Preference
sec.p: The inductions of rotational direction so far involved both motor and visual components since participants manipulated objects and also received visual feedback on this performance. As a further generalization, we tested whether merely passive perception of an objection rotation would also influence novelty preference. We used a rotating square (instead, for instance, a dot moving in a circle) as inducer to avoid visual similarities with clocks or loading animations in the Internet.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: A total of 81 (51 female and 30 male; 71 right-handers and 10 left-handers) German individuals from different professional backgrounds participated for a reward of €2 (approximately US$4 then).

sec.title: Material and Procedure
sec.p: As visual rotation induction, a black square was used appearing 7 × 7 cm large on a white background on the PC screen rotating either clockwise or counterclockwise (66.67 r/min). Both the mere exposure paradigm (Experiment 1) and the openness to experience measure (Experiment 2) were replicated (with their sequence counterbalanced across participants) with the following modification. Before each trial (each Chinese ideograph with subsequent preference rating and each item of the openness to experience scale), the rotating square was presented for 3,000 ms, with rotation direction manipulated between participants (clockwise n = 41, counterclockwise n = 40).

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p: The preference ratings in the mere exposure paradigm yielded a significant interaction between Exposure (old vs. new; within) and Square Rotation Direction (clockwise vs. counterclockwise; between), F(1, 79) = 9.54, p < .003, ηp 2 = .11, and no other effects (ps < .12). Participants who were seeing a square rotating counterclockwise liked old (M counterclockwise-old = 4.27, SD = 1.29) more than novel stimuli (M counterclockwise-new = 3.89, SD = 1.37), t(39) = 4.71, p < .001, d = 0.29. However, participants who were seeing the square rotating clockwise did not show a reliable difference between old (M counterclockwise-old = 3.71, SD = 1.25) and novel stimuli (M counterclockwise-new = 3.83, SD = 1.41), t < 1, p = .40.

The aggregated openness to experience scale (Cronbach’s α = .85) ranged from −0.50 to 1.75 (M = 0.87, SD = 0.56). Participants who were seeing the square rotating clockwise scored higher (M clockwise = 0.99, SD = 0.53) than participants who were seeing the square rotating counterclockwise (M counterclockwise = 0.74, SD = 0.56), t(79) = 2.04, p < .044, d = 0.46.

Thus, the mere perception of a rotating square interspersed between items had a similar impact on novelty preference and openness to experience as turning movements had had in Experiments 1 and 2. However, this perceptual rotation induction yielded a comparably smaller impact than the motor turning induction. It did not reverse but only attenuated the mere exposure effect—clockwise rotation induction did not induce a preference toward novel stimuli but rather an indifference—and showed a smaller effect size in modulating openness to experience.

Concerning the locus of the present causal factors, it is interesting that passive viewing of an object rotating still influenced novelty orientation. However, this apparently purely perceptual induction does not rule out motor components because we cannot watch a rotating stimulus without rotating our eyes ourselves; thus, the present induction also instigated rotational motor/oculomotor activity (cf., Topolinski, 2010).

One final objection is that although we used nonverbal rotation instructions, participants may have labeled the present moving directions spontaneously (e.g., clockwise, or to the right), allowing for semantic priming mechanisms beyond mere sensorimotor paths (cf., Eder & Rothermund, 2008). This alternative explanation was ruled out in the final experiment.

sec.title: Experiment 4: Exploration Behavior
sec.p: The present phenomenon should be generalized to a turning induction that prevents semantic labeling effects (Eder & Rothermund, 2008) and to actual exploration behavior, which is a central dimension of novelty seeking (Zuckerman, 1984). Thus, participants were asked to choose jelly beans from a variety of more and less conventional flavors from a “Lazy Susan”—that is, a rotating turntable—that could only be moved in one direction.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: A total of 50 (40 female and 10 male; 39 right-handers and 11 left-handers) individuals from various professional backgrounds participated for a reward of €1 (approximately US$1.5 then).

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: A wooden circular turntable 60 cm in diameter (the Lazy Susan) was placed on a conventional desk (Figure 2 ). A hidden locking mechanism could be switched between participants to allow only clockwise or counterclockwise rotation of this turntable (n = 25 in each condition). If being turned into the other direction, the turntable would block. This mechanical constraint rendered any turning instruction unnecessary and prevented a spontaneous semantic labeling of the turning movement. The candy was an assortment of 16 flavors of jelly beans that were easily available for purchase in Germany.

caption.p: The Lazy Susan used in Experiment 2.

sec.p: In a pretest, N = 10 independent raters indicated on an 11-point Likert-type scale how conventional (0) or unusual (10) the name of each flavor was. The name of the sort rather than its taste was rated because later participants would also base their choice on the names. Based on these ratings, the relatively conventional flavors were apple, cherry, coconut, lime, lemon, orange, peach, and strawberry; and the relatively unconventional flavors were blueberry, popcorn, chewing gum, chocolate, cotton candy, marshmallow, melon, and punch. One token of each flavor was placed in a small plastic cup on the edge of the circular turntable (Figure 2). The name of each sort was depicted on a small sign beneath the cup so that participants had to rotate the turntable to read the names before choosing. The sequence of flavors around the table was in alphabetic order of the German names, thus random with respect to conventional and unconventional sorts.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: At the end of an experimental session involving various unrelated tasks, participants were led to the turntable and were asked to read each of the depicted names of the candy sorts and to choose 5 of the 16 flavors as a candy reward for their participation, in addition to their monetary compensation. To unobtrusively indicate the rotation direction, the experimenter gently turned the turntable a few degrees when introducing it to the participant. Then, the experimenter left the participant alone going to her working desk on the other side of the laboratory from which she could observe and record the hand (right or left) with which the participant turned the Lazy Susan. After their choice participants were dismissed, their choice could be recorded on the basis of the emptied cups on the Lazy Susan.

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p: Those participants who were assigned the clockwise turntable chose a greater number of unconventional flavors (M clockwise = 2.48, SD = 1.29) than participants using the counterclockwise turntable (M counterclockwise = 1.72, SD = 1.34), t(48) = 2.04, p < .047, d = 0.57. Between the two turning groups, the number of participants using their right, their left, or both hands for turning did not differ reliably (clockwise: 18 right, 2 left, and 5 both; counterclockwise, 16 right, 3 left, and 6 both; ts < 1). Inserting handedness as a control variable did not change the effect. Thus, the mere turning direction of the Lazy Susan affected participants’ overt exploration behavior, with clockwise compared to counterclockwise turning increasing the tendency to choose unconventional, or novel, sorts by 44%. It is important to emphasize that the current motor task, namely, to turn the Lazy Susan slightly to read the candy names, did not require any labeling of the movement, rendering semantic priming effects unlikely.

sec.title: General Discussion
sec.p: The present experiments show that the rotational direction of meaningless body movements and even passively perceived rotating objects substantially shape novelty orientation, with clockwise compared to counterclockwise rotation increasing preference and openness to novelty as well as exploration behavior. We argue that these effects were triggered by the abstract sensorimotor symbol (Barsalou, 1999) of rotational direction, which activates according to temporal representations (similar to other, static spatial features, Boroditsky, 2000, 2001; Casasanto & Boroditsky, 2008), with clockwise rotation implying progression and thus inducing a novelty preference (Bardo et al., 1996; Roberti, 2004; Zuckerman, 1984) and counterclockwise rotation implying regression and thus inducing a familiarity mind-set (De Vries et al., 2010; Hansen & Topolinski, 2011).

This abstract representation of rotational direction could be activated by circular movements (turning cranks, Experiment 1), linear movements that effected an object rotation (rotating paper towels, turning a Lazy Susan, Experiments 2 and 4), and merely perceiving a rotating object without any motor task, thus, covering visual, motor, and proprioceptive domains. The finding that the passive perceptual induction (Experiment 3) yielded less pronounced effects than the motor tasks (Experiments 1 and 2) suggests that the sensorimotor representation of rotational direction is additively constituted by different domains because the perceptual induction only involved visual (but see below), while the motor tasks involved both motor and visual information. However, a precise disentangling of the driving modalities (e.g., visual vs. proprioceptive) should be attempted in future research since the apparently purely perceptual induction in Experiment 3 (seeing a rotating square) still involved motor components, namely eye movements that necessarily accompany visual stimulus perception (Topolinski, 2010). Beyond this, we assume that rotational direction can be induced by other domains as well, such as the vestibular system (e.g., turning a person sitting in a revolving chair).

Especially the involvement of visual and motor components leads to interesting further research questions because both these factors can be pitted against each other, for instance when facing a target person who is turning something, for instance a barrel organ player. In this case, the visual information is reversed to the target’s performed direction, but automatic mimicry processes or perspective taking might induce the original turning direction; an effect that is likely moderated by perspective taking and perceiver–target relationship (cf., Hawk, Fischer, & Van Kleef, 2011).

As we have argued, we assume that the mapping between rotational and temporal direction is acquired through massive sensorimotor experience in both perceiving perceptual symbols (e.g., clocks) and operating on rotational gadgets (e.g., volume control; Zwaan & Taylor, 2006; Zwaan, Taylor, & de Boer, 2010); a learning experience that is likely found in most individuals because rotational symbols are omnipresent. However, specific motor expertise, for instance, in craftsmen, film editors, or disk jockeys, might even enhance the present effects. On the other hand, a concurrent motor interference (e.g., performing clockwise hand movements while watching counterclockwise object rotations) may disturb them (cf., Topolinski & Strack, 2009, 2010).

Finally, it should be mentioned that the current mapping between rotational and temporal direction goes beyond the Spatial Numerical Association of Response Codes (SNARC) effect (Dehaene, 1992), which is the finding that increasing numbers (i.e., numerical progression) are mentally represented from left to right. This left-to-right increase is only true for the upper semicircle of a clockwise arrangement but is reversed for the lower semicircle. As a consequence, the SNARC effect can be reversed for clockwise number arrangements (Bächtold, Baumüller, & Brugger, 1998).

Future research might also address even further reaching cognitive and motivational consequences in ecological settings, such as the turning direction of revolving doors and passengers’ consumer behavior or wheels of fortunes in risk taking and gambling.
